name: 2-bromo-3-iodo-5-methylpyridine
Reason: 2-bromo-3-iodo-5-methylpyridine has a melting point that we will compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a methyl group, a bromine atom, and an iodine atom. The methyl group adds approximately +10°C due to increased molecular weight and rigidity. The bromine atom introduces a strong withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The iodine atom also introduces a significant dipole, raising the melting point by approximately +20°C.
